dialog: Hi Medi, I have a question about how the flu virus works.
Sure, I'd be happy to help. What would you like to know?
Can you explain how the virus enters our cells?

Of course. The virus enters our cells by binding to the sialic acid receptors on the surface of the cell membrane using the HA proteins on the surface of the envelope. For certain types of the virus, the NA protein can also help initiate entry.
What happens after the virus enters our cells?

After binding, the virus is internalized into a cell by an endosome that contains the virion inside it. The endosome is acidified by cellular vATPase to have lower pH, which triggers a conformational change in HA that allows fusion of the viral envelope with the endosomal membrane. At the same time, hydrogen ions diffuse into the virion through M2 ion channels, disrupting internal protein-protein interactions to release RNPs into the host cell's cytosol.
That's really interesting. What are RNPs?
RNPs are ribonucleoproteins, which are complexes of the viral RNA genome and viral nucleoprotein. The M1 protein shell surrounding RNPs is then degraded, fully uncoating RNPs in the cytosol.
Thanks for explaining that. It's really helpful to know.

knowledge: Influenza Influenza Binding is mediated by the viral HA proteins on the surface of the envelope, which bind to cells that contain sialic acid receptors on the surface of the cell membrane.  For N1 subtypes with the "G147R" mutation and N2 subtypes, the NA protein can initiate entry. After binding, the virus is internalized into the cell by an endosome that contains the virion inside it.  The endosome is acidified by cellular vATPase to have lower pH, which triggers a conformational change in HA that allows fusion of the viral envelope with the endosomal membrane.  At the same time, hydrogen ions diffuse into the virion through M2 ion channels, disrupting internal protein-protein interactions to release RNPs into the host cell's cytosol.
